posts.cooked: Last Saturday I decided to use the robot characterization routine using the SysID software provided by WPILib. I am wondering how I can use the data or how did the data other teams have gathered helped them program their robot. I also wanted to ask about the Sim RMSE value. When I conducted the tests and viewed the data I got a RMSE value of 35.931. I am wondering if this is too high and I should disregard the data I collected or take the fact that the data I collected may be wrong and tread lightly if I plan to use any of the data.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Please share your diagnostic plots and data.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
Hey! It’s really cool that you accomplished this, great job!

I hope you will get a solid answer from others about the cool ways you can use the results you got, places where you can compare your results to what others have gotten, and what the RMSE result might mean about the quality of the test.

I’m curious to know if there was anything in particular that led you to the decision to invest your time into the characterization, despite not having a plan for how you might use the results next?

Thank you so much for your time. I put the screenshots for the data: I can’t upload csv or jsons so hopefully this is fine. Capture1 1112×821 112 KB Capture2 1755×911 172 KB Capture3 907×951 72.4 KB Capture4 874×310 22.8 KB

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The units don’t match between the images in your post; on one image the units are specified as meters and units-per-rotation is equal to 1, while in another the units are specified as inches and units per rotation is equal to 6.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: I invested time into robot characterization because I was hoped it would help me get a start with getting values for feedforward and pid as well because in past years we haven’t done too much on it.  This is an old robot from 2020 so its long gone since its original creators so I don’t have a lot of guidance in terms of advanced control
You’re absolutely right. This is my bad. I don’t think I saved the config for the logger right or at all. But I’m sure that it was adjusted for 6inch at the time of testing

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Okay, so there are a couple things that stand out to me: your units are in inches, but your values are huge even then.  Your robot was not going 1000 inches/second at the end of the quasistatic test.

The graphs and R^2 look fine, so this is almost certainly a unit scaling issue.  Check all the relevant values (including units per rotation) carefully.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: Ok I will probably redo my testing tomorrow. I just want to confirm my values already. I know we have six inch wheels but do I have to manually multiply six inches by pi or is that already handled for me. As well, we use TalonFX falcon 500 which use the integrated encoder, which has 2048 counts per revolution. We used a custom drivetrain with a gear ratio of 8.4 I believe. so the gearing is 1:8.4. I don’t know how important voltages are but I know we operate with very little space so I have to raise the quasistatic voltage and lower the dynamic. Hopefully this is good place to continue testing. Thank you once again for your time. I really appreciate this because we don’t have a programming mentor so I really am on my own most of the time

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
iwumbo:

so the gearing is 1:8.4

Usually gearing is turns input:turns output, not the other way around.  This might be one of your problems.
